resources.string:
1) Underweight:

Breakfast: Include a combination of carbohydrates (whole grains, fruits), protein (eggs, yogurt, nuts), and healthy fats (avocado, nut butter).


Lunch: Opt for a balanced meal with complex carbohydrates (brown rice, quinoa), lean proteins (chicken, fish, tofu), healthy fats (olive oil, seeds), and plenty of vegetables.


Dinner: Similar to lunch, focus on a mix of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats. Include a variety of nutrient-dense foods to increase calorie intake.

2) Normal Weight:

Breakfast: Include a source of carbohydrates (oatmeal, whole grain bread), protein (eggs, Greek yogurt), and fruits or vegetables for added nutrients.


Lunch: Aim for a balanced meal with lean proteins (chicken, fish, legumes), whole grains (brown rice, whole wheat pasta), healthy fats (avocado, olive oil), and vegetables.


Dinner: Similar to lunch, ensure a balance of macronutrients with an emphasis on whole foods, including lean proteins, complex carbohydrates, and vegetables.

3) Overweight:

Breakfast: Choose a high-fiber cereal or oatmeal with fresh fruits and a source of lean protein (such as Greek yogurt or boiled eggs).


Lunch: Focus on a combination of lean proteins (chicken breast, turkey), whole grains (quinoa, whole wheat bread), healthy fats (nuts, seeds), and vegetables.


Dinner: Opt for lean proteins (fish, skinless poultry), whole grains (barley, brown rice), and plenty of vegetables. Limit added fats and sugars.

4) Obese:
Breakfast: Prioritize high-fiber foods like whole grains, fruits, and vegetables, along with a source of lean protein (such as egg whites or low-fat dairy).


Lunch: Include lean proteins (grilled chicken, beans), whole grains (whole wheat bread, quinoa), healthy fats (avocado, olive oil), and vegetables.


Dinner: Emphasize lean proteins (fish, tofu), complex carbohydrates (sweet potatoes, whole wheat pasta), non-starchy vegetables, and limit added fats and sugars.
